description: The Irrigation Peak Rewards program offers financial incentives to agricultural irrigation customers for allowing Idaho Power to remotely turn off specific irrigation pumps during peak demand periods. The program runs seasonally from June 15 to September 15 with a minimum of three load control events per season. Participants can choose from three interruption options (Early, Standard, or Extended) with varying event windows and payment rates. This is an agriculture-specific load control program designed for irrigation pump equipment, NOT a general-purpose demand response program for battery energy storage systems.

customer_classes.size_threshold_notes: Program is exclusively for agricultural irrigation customers with irrigation pumps. Pumps 30 HP or less have a one-time $500 enrollment fee for new participants. All irrigation pumps are eligible regardless of size.

seasonal_rates.notes: Fixed incentive per billing kW for Early Option (3pm-9pm window)
Fixed incentive per billing kW for Standard Option (3pm-10pm window)
Fixed incentive per billing kW for Extended Option (3pm-11pm window)
Fixed energy credit for Early Option
Fixed energy credit for Standard Option
Fixed energy credit for Extended Option
Variable incentive per event kWh reduced (paid after 3rd event) - Early Option
Variable incentive per event kWh reduced (paid after 3rd event) - Standard Option
Variable incentive per event kWh reduced (paid after 3rd event) - Extended Option

penalty_structure.penalty_description: Opt-out fees apply when customer calls to opt out of a load control event. Early Option opt-out fee: $3.25 per billed demand (kW). Standard and Extended Option opt-out fee: $6.25 per billed demand (kW). Customers can opt out by calling 208-388-2534 preferably 1 hour before event, but can call during event.

nomination_bidding.nomination_deadline: Spring enrollment period - enrollment packets mailed to eligible customers
nomination_bidding.bidding_structure: No price bidding - customers select interruption option (Early, Standard, or Extended) for each enrolled pump

special_attributes: Agriculture-specific program for irrigation pumps only
Not applicable to battery energy storage systems
Requires Idaho Power-installed load control devices or manual load control for large facilities
Program expanded in 2025 to all irrigation customers
Variable incentive payment changed from 4th event to 3rd event in 2025
One-time $500 enrollment fee for pumps 30 HP or less that have not previously participated

program_evolution.change_description: Program expanded to ALL irrigation customers (previously limited). New Early Interruption Option added (3pm-9pm window). Variable incentive payment changed from after 4th event to after 3rd event.

data_sources.source_name: Idaho Power Irrigation Peak Rewards Main Page
Idaho Power Irrigation Peak Rewards FAQ

data_sources.notes: Oregon Schedule 23 - Irrigation Peak Rewards Program (Optional)

integration_metadata.notes: Data quality score is 7/10. Program details, payment rates, and structure are well-documented for 2025. However, this program is NOT suitable for battery energy storage systems - it is exclusively designed for agricultural irrigation pump load control. Historical event data not available. Tariff information confirmed to be Oregon Schedule 23, though specific tariff PDF was not accessible. No information about battery eligibility because this is an agriculture-specific program.

battery_suitability.justification: This program is NOT suitable for battery energy storage systems. The Irrigation Peak Rewards program is exclusively designed for agricultural irrigation customers with irrigation pumps. The program name explicitly states 'Irrigation' and all eligibility requirements specify agricultural irrigation equipment. The program provides load control of irrigation pumps through Idaho Power-installed devices or manual control. While the payment structure includes capacity-type payments ($2.75-$5.25/kW) and variable energy payments ($0.09-$0.25/kWh reduced), these are designed for pump load curtailment, not battery dispatch. Battery energy storage systems would not qualify for this program as they are not irrigation pumps. Idaho Power may have separate demand response programs for commercial/industrial customers or battery systems, but this specific program is agriculture-only.
key_limitations_for_batteries: Eligibility restricted to agricultural irrigation customers only
Program designed for irrigation pump equipment, not energy storage
Requires installation of load control devices on irrigation pumps
Payment structure tied to pump curtailment, not battery operations
No mention of battery eligibility in any program documentation

potential_annual_revenue_1mw_1mwh.calculation_methodology: NOT APPLICABLE - Program does not accept battery systems
potential_annual_revenue_1mw_1mwh.notes: Revenue calculation not applicable. This is an agriculture-specific irrigation pump program that does not accept battery energy storage systems. For battery revenue opportunities with Idaho Power, research other commercial/industrial demand response programs if available.

research_summary.key_finding: This is an agriculture-specific demand response program for irrigation pump load control. It is NOT applicable to battery energy storage systems. The program offers three interruption options (Early, Standard, Extended) with capacity payments ranging from $2.75-$5.25/kW and variable energy payments of $0.09-$0.25/kWh for load reduction, but these payments are exclusively for agricultural irrigation customers with irrigation pumps.
research_summary.data_integrity: All data sourced from official Idaho Power website. No data invented. Payment rates, event windows, and program structure verified from multiple official sources. Clearly documented that this program is agriculture-specific and not applicable to battery systems.
research_summary.program_classification: Agricultural Load Control - Irrigation Equipment Only
research_summary.recommendation_for_battery_optimization: DO NOT pursue this program for battery energy storage systems - it is exclusively for agricultural irrigation customers. The program name 'Irrigation Peak Rewards' and all eligibility requirements confirm this is agriculture-specific. For battery opportunities with Idaho Power, research whether Idaho Power offers commercial/industrial demand response programs or time-of-use rates that could benefit battery operations. This program should not be included in battery optimization models.
missing_information: Total enrolled capacity or number of participants
Actual performance metrics from past seasons
Oregon Schedule 23 tariff PDF (confirmed to exist but not accessible)
Information about other Idaho Power programs that may accept batteries
verified_information: Three interruption options: Early (3pm-9pm), Standard (3pm-10pm), Extended (3pm-11pm)
Variable incentive paid after 3rd event (changed from 4th in 2025)
Minimum 3 events per season, maximum 60 hours per season
Events up to 4 hours per day, up to 16 hours per week
Program exclusively for agricultural irrigation customers with irrigation pumps
$500 one-time enrollment fee for pumps 30 HP or less (new participants)
Program expanded to all irrigation customers in 2025

comparison_to_typical_dr_programs.summary: This is an agriculture-specific load control program, fundamentally different from commercial/industrial demand response programs that accept battery systems. While the payment structure superficially resembles DR programs (capacity + energy payments), the eligibility is restricted to irrigation pumps only. Typical battery-compatible DR programs have commercial/industrial eligibility with minimum capacity thresholds measured in kW of dispatchable load/generation, whereas this program measures in HP of irrigation pump equipment.
key_differences_from_battery_programs: Eligibility: Agriculture irrigation only vs. Commercial/Industrial customers
Equipment: Irrigation pumps vs. Battery energy storage systems
Measurement: Horsepower (HP) vs. Kilowatts (kW) of battery capacity
Load Control: Curtailment of irrigation pumps vs. Battery discharge/charge
Season: Irrigation season (Jun-Sep) vs. Year-round or summer peak programs
Geographic: Agricultural areas vs. Urban/suburban commercial zones
Payment basis: Load reduction of pumps vs. Battery dispatch or capacity availability
